newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares seek revival, keep eye on U.S..
newsitem.headline: German shares seek revival, keep eye on U.S..

text.p: German shares edged up in early trade on Friday and held onto the gains to end bourse trade higher as the DAX index hurdled an important level.
The 30-share DAX index ended the bourse up 22.77 points at 3,602.19 points and finished above 3,600-point level.
The market got a boost from two German state inflation reports that showed higher prices in May on a monthly basis but failed to ignite fears about inflation growth.
Firmer German debt prices and a higher dollar also helped to underpin the market, which was expected to keep an eye on Wall Street in afternoon post-bourse IBIS electronic dealings.

Traders said the DAX's ability to retain earlier gains and finish above 3,600 points could keep up the advance in pursuit of the DAX record during bourse trade of 3,618.24 points. But Monday's U.S. market holiday may keep movements range-bound.
Among specific shares, carmaker Volkswagen AG ended up 13 marks at 1,140 marks after briefly pushing through technical resistance at 1,150 marks.

Dresdner Bank, Germany's second largest bank, gained 1.02 marks to 62.82 marks after saying it was optimistic for higher full-year results and dividend payout after a 10 percent rise in first quarter profits.
The bank also denied media reports that it was interested in taking a stake in Postbank, the state-owned bank currently tied to the postal system.

Software firm SAP ended trade steady at 316.50 marks amid what dealers said was continued concern over allegations of insider trading despite a statement from state prosecutors on Thursday clearing 71 SAP staff of suspicion.
But Frankfurt prosecutors said on Friday that their probe would now focus on banks and non-employees of SAP who have ties to the firm.
